sub_title: Scientist/ Project Manager at The Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies of Johnson & Johnson
summary:
I am a pharmacist by training and have a Ph.D. degree in drug delivery and immuno-oncology. I have comprehensive hands-on experience designing and conducting early-stage research in personalised medicines, state-of-the-art drug delivery and formulation development for immunology, oncology, and cardiovascular treatments. On top of that, I have scientific expertise and understanding of preclinical and clinical development to guarantee efficient treatment and patient safety. I am a problem solver with extensive project management experiences both in academic and industrial settings.

I successfully mentored and supervised research professionals on collaborative projects in an interdisciplinary and intercultural environment, which enabled me to develop high adaptability, and resilience with a high sense of accountability and fairness. I have good interpersonal and communication skills, to present and discuss scientific discoveries to different audiences at meetings, conferences, workshops, and journal publications.

I am a fast learner, passionate in delivering innovative science, personalized medicines and promoting human health.

profile_positions.company: Faculty of Pharmacy of the University of Lisbon
profile_positions.description: Teaching and managing group of Ph.D. students. Guiding development of multicomponent nano-platforms for immune modulation in cancer. Preclinical testing of developed immunotherapeutic polymeric nano-vaccines.
profile_positions.title: Technology Transfer and Teaching Professional and BioNanoSciences–Drug Delivery & Immunotherapy

profile_positions.company: Faculty of Pharmacy of the University of Lisbon
profile_positions.description:
Development and optimization of nano-vaccine for induction of anti-tumor immunity in melanoma and breast cancer. Physicochemical characterization of polymeric nanoplatform systems, namely nanoparticle size, surface charge, entrapment efficacy, stability and release. In vitro and in vivo preclinical testing of nanovaccine stability and efficacy in steady-state and cancerous conditions. Using various techniques, such as Flow cytometry and ImageStreamX to best distinguish nanoparticle-cell and cell-to-cell interaction in the activated immune system. Evaluation of tumor reduction and/or elimination and animal survival. Overall, my job was composed of experiment organization, technical transfer and optimization, data analysis, result presentation and writing of > 7 scientific papers, 3 reviewers and grant proposals (ERA-NET EuroNanoMed II (ENMed/0051/2016), COMPETE2020 and FCT (SAICTPAC/0019/2015)).

Department of Drug Development
http://imed.ulisboa.pt/research/program-areas/drug-development/intracellular-trafficking-modulation-for-advanced-drug-delivery-research/

profile_positions.title: Research Scientist

profile_positions.description:
Various projects, which were led by my mentors, peers or me. 
Using novel state-of-the-art nano-delivery systems to study cell-to-cell interactions. 
The most important projects were Single-cell resolution of DC–T cell interactome in the antigen-challenged lymph node and Antigen uptake and presentation by mononuclear phagocytes in the Peyer’s patch. 

Publication: 
DC Respond to Cognate T Cell Interaction in the Antigen-Challenged Lymph Node. Front Immunol, 2019.
Intravital visualization of interactions of murine Peyer's Patch-resident dendritic cells with M cells. Eur J Immunol, 2019 

Department of Immunology

profile_positions.title: Project Advisor and Technology Transfer Scientist at the Immunology Department

profile_positions.description:
I collaborated with the laboratory of Prof. Ronit Satchi-Fainaro from the Department of Physiology and Pharmacology at the Sackler School of Medicine, Tel Aviv University. Project: In vitro and in vivo efficacy study of dendritic cell-targeted peptide vaccine against melanoma by ligand-modified nanoparticles.

Publication: Immunization with mannosylated nano-vaccines and inhibition of the immune-suppressing microenvironment sensitizes melanoma to immune checkpoint modulators. Nature Nanotechnology, 2019.
profile_positions.title: Project Specialist & Technology Transfer at the Sackler School of Medicine
